header.title: The Scroll of Set, Issue Number 29

central_thesis: The overarching thesis of this issue of The Scroll of Set is the exploration and practical application of 'Xeper' (Coming Into Being/Self-Deification) within the philosophical and organizational framework of the Temple of Set. It emphasizes conscious evolution, the nuanced challenges of magical practice, and the internal governance and degree system crucial for individual Setian advancement.

structure_content.summary: This article defines Xeper as 'Coming into Being' or 'creation,' a profound and absolute concept that entails conscious, often challenging, change. It highlights Xeper's dual nature, offering the potential for mastery over the self and the universe, but also for self-destruction if not approached with careful consideration. The author stresses the need for conscious, self-directed creation to avoid 'unmaking' oneself.

This piece outlines the path to 'Becoming' as a Setian, emphasizing 'creation and change' over preservation. It defines the goal as evolving into an entity capable of independent action against the 'Cosmic Inertia' (natural order), advocating for the transformation of one's 'inside force' (Will) to influence natural laws rather than attempting to destroy them. The article proposes a three-step process for Xeper: (1) creation and change, (2) control of consciousness and will through effort, and (3) assimilation of knowledge.

This article provides a structured, ten-step methodology for constructing effective magical rituals. It covers defining precise goals, identifying situational elements, selecting a 'key element' for influence, minimizing required power, converting elements into meaningful symbols, constructing a 'simulacrum' for manipulation, executing the ritual, ensuring equilibrium of the new path, confidently leveraging the altered situation, and meticulously recording results. The author also draws parallels between magical and scientific methodologies.

This article discusses the role of errors in the Xeper process, asserting their necessity for growth and learning. It contrasts the constructive learning from errors in the Æon of Set with the destructive chaos of the Æon of HarWer. The author frames 'excommunication' from the Temple of Set as a corrective 'tool' for the order's self-preservation, ensuring the integrity of the Setian path.

This brief note refers to a previous article on 'On the Day and Hour of the Sun' and suggests Lyall Watson's 'Supernature' as a resource for understanding the principles behind 'magical timing' within Setian practice.

This administrative note announces the resignations of Magister Robert Ethel and Priest Roland Holt, who cited 'gross misdirection' and 'corruption' within the Temple of Set. Michael A. Aquino V° refutes these claims, attributing Ethel's departure to discomfort with the Temple's open-disclosure and checks-and-balances, and Holt's to loyalty to Ethel. It also details ongoing Council of Nine elections and Ruby Tablet supervision changes.

This informational article provides details about the 'Treasures of Tutankhamen' exhibition, including tour dates and locations. It also describes a service for Temple members to rent a slide and tape set of the exhibition for educational purposes, highlighting the Temple's initiative to make such cultural resources available to its membership.

structure_content.chapter_title: Close Encounters of the Second Degree
structure_content.summary: This article elucidates the II° Recognition within the Temple of Set, clarifying that it signifies an individual's 'potential for Coming Into Being as an Adept,' not an achievement award. It explains that access to advanced Temple materials is contingent upon II° recognition to ensure genuine aptitude and prevent 'vampirization.' The author defines an Adept as one who successfully applies philosophy and techniques. It distinguishes between a 'magician' (one who translates experience into language) and a 'mystic' (one who does not), emphasizing the importance of communication in Xeper. The article also details the nature of III°+ (Priesthood) as a recognition of a 'singular quality,' and stresses that degrees reflect flexible 'states of being' consistent with free will, not fixed 'awards.'

key_concepts.definition: The central process of 'Coming into Being' or 'creation' within Setian philosophy. It refers to a conscious, willed self-evolution and self-deification, involving profound personal change, development of will and consciousness, and the assimilation of knowledge. It is described as a 'double-edged sword' due to its potential for mastery or self-destruction.

A concept from the 'Statement of Leviathan' representing the ultimate mastery over the universe, achieved through its 'obliteration.' It signifies an extreme form of individual sovereignty and transformation, beyond conventional power or glory.

The 'Opposite Self' to Set, representing a primal state before the full development of individual identity. It is associated with being part of the Cosmos and achieving identity by becoming what the Cosmic Order was not, often linked to chaos and destructive processes.

The natural order or 'God,' from which the Setian must learn to act independently. Setian philosophy advises against attempting to destroy or displace Cosmic Inertia, as doing so would lead to a loss of individual distinction and the 'One' becoming 'All.'
An adherent or practitioner of the philosophy and practices of the Temple of Set, dedicated to self-evolution, the development of the Black Flame, and the process of Xeper.

Within the Temple of Set's degree system, the II° is a recognition of an individual's *potential* for 'Coming Into Being' and successful application of Setian philosophy and techniques, rather than an 'achievement award.' It grants access to advanced Temple materials and signifies a commitment to the Xeper process.

A hierarchical system of recognition, not awards, reflecting an individual's 'state of being' and progress in Xeper. The I° is a screening process; the II° (Adept) signifies potential for Xeper; and the III°+ (Priesthood) denotes a 'singular quality' identifying the Priesthood, not a linear continuation of lower degrees. Degrees are considered flexible and can change.
A publication or internal communication channel of the Temple of Set, distinct from The Scroll, designed to be a two-way channel for information exchange, member submissions, and research.

A crucial distinction made in Setian philosophy: a 'magician' is one who can translate their magical visions and experiences into coherent language and draw meaningful conclusions, allowing for understanding and evaluation. A 'mystic,' conversely, floats in a 'dream-world' without articulating or understanding their experiences.

practical_system.description: The practical system described is centered on 'Xeper' – conscious, willed self-evolution and 'Coming into Being.' This involves cultivating an independent Will and heightened consciousness, acquiring and assimilating knowledge, and applying these faculties to actively create desired changes in one's life and environment, often in deliberate opposition to the 'Cosmic Inertia.' Rituals are a key operative component, methodically designed to influence situations by symbolically representing elements, constructing simulacra, and broadcasting 'power' to effect specific outcomes. The system emphasizes rigorous self-observation, disciplined effort, and the articulation of magical experience into coherent language, distinguishing effective 'magicians' from passive 'mystics.'
tools: Ritual staff (stainless steel and lexan, continuously glowing or flashing)
Simulacra (constructed symbolic representations for ritual manipulation)
Hexadecimal symbol sets (for Temple of Set communication)
rituals: Ritual Building (a structured methodology for creating and executing rituals, including goal definition, elemental analysis, symbolic conversion, simulacrum construction, power projection, and outcome recording)
Conjurations (e.g., Dragons, Null Vortex for destroying dreams, Computer Bug for eating parity bits)

relevant_quotes.text: It is only by the obliteration of the universe that is may man seal his mastery of the Black Flame...
Xeper is a very delicate concept. It is an absolute, not an on-off proposition. Aspiring towards Xeper means change, possibly in many ways we never would have conceived before.

We must aspire to the fullness of Xeper with careful consideration, and we must create concert, not with the universe but with ourselves, lest we become unmade, for Xeper very definitely offers that potential as well.

Were I my Self to displace the Cosmic Inertia, I should be forced to become a new measure of consistency. I would cease to be One, for I should become All. But, as I have said, I cannot destroy the Cosmic Inertia without having to assume its place. And so HarWer must exist while Set exists.

But HarWer, my Opposite Self, is a strange and fitful presence. I, Set, am my Self distinct from the Order of the Cosmos, yet am ordered in and of my Self. HarWer I was when I was once part of the Cosmos and could achieve identity only by becoming what the Cosmic Order was not. By HarWer I cancelled the imbalance, leaving a void in which true Creation could take form as Set.
Without work on consciousness all the sides of us that can be conscious will become more and more mechanical.
The magician is one who can "see the big picture" and determine the appropriate controls for guiding it towards desired ends.
Until you have rendered that experience into language, you yourself will neither be able to understand it nor be able to do anything with it.
These degrees are not awards or certificates of completion that are bestowed; they are a recognition of an individual's state of being.

critical_analysis.relevance: This issue of The Scroll of Set is highly relevant for understanding the foundational philosophy and practical application of Setianism in the late 1970s. It deeply articulates the core concept of Xeper, its inherent challenges, and its role in personal and magical evolution. The detailed 'Ritual Building' guide provides a rare insight into the operative mechanics of Setian magic. Furthermore, discussions on the Temple's degree system, internal governance, and the distinction between 'magician' and 'mystic' offer critical context for situating the Temple of Set within the broader landscape of modern Western Esotericism and Left Hand Path traditions, highlighting its emphasis on individual sovereignty, conscious development, and disciplined practice.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of existing members of the Temple of Set, particularly those at the II° (Adept) level or aspiring to it, as the content directly addresses their path of Xeper, ritual practice, and organizational structure. Additionally, it serves as a valuable resource for academic researchers, occult practitioners, and individuals outside the Temple interested in understanding the philosophical tenets, practical methodologies, and internal dynamics of a prominent modern magical order.
